text.p: These are the leading stories in the Sarajevo press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Bosnia's Council of Ministers again fails to reach agreement on its working procedure. Moslem co-chairman of the council, Haris Silajdzic, blames Bosnian Serb request that deputy ministers be members of the council which he says would lead to country's division. He proposes resignation of all the body's members if no agreement can be reached.

- Bosnia's Moslem-Croat Federation government, meeting despite a boycott by Croat ministers, revokes a decision by Croat finance minister Drago Bilandzija to exempt the private Lijanovic company from paying taxes.

- Croat ministers in Bosnia's Moslem-Croat Federation government say they walked out of a government session because their request for adopting legislation on the constitution of new municipalities has been refused by Moslem officials on political grounds.

- The arbitration decision on the disputed north Bosnian town of Brcko will be a test for international community's consistency in implementing the Dayton peace accord, the ruling Moslem Party of Democratic Action (SDA) says.

- Mirza Hajric, an adviser to chairman of Bosnian collective Presidency Alija Izetbegovic denies Los Angeles Times report that Bosnia is setting up intelligence service under Iranian influence. "Only legal organisations are doing that job and I'm convinced they will soon come up with an official explanation or a statement."
- Michael Steiner, deputy to the international High Representative for Bosnia suggests that Sarajevo should elect a mayor who can represent multi-ethnicity and multi-cultural tradition of city.

- U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) donates 165 million German Marks for reviving Bosnia's commerce, governor of the Bosnian National Bank Kasim Omicevic says. --Sarajevo newsroom, +387-71-663-864.
